question: What requirements must the data of the Argo International Program meet to be accepted by the receiving centers?

answers.answer: They must include temperature, salinity and pressure.
They must include temperature, salinity, pressure and quality controls.
They must include temperature and pressure, quality controls, and be freely available.
They must include temperature, salinity and pressure, and the data are freely and freely distributed.

question: The coverage objective of the Argo fleet, as established by the Argo Science Team at the beginning of the program, was:

answers.answer: An average coverage of one Argo float every 3 degrees in longitude and latitude.
Have around 10,000 operational floats regularly distributed in the global ocean.
Have floats spaced on an average mesh of 50x50 km.
Double the number of floats every 3 years until 2020.

question: In relation to the Argo floats currently deployed in the ocean, select the incorrect statement.

answers.answer: They measure salinity, temperature and depth.
Some are making salinity measurements at depths greater than 2000m.
All floats have an Argos transmission system.
Some floats have incorporated particulate organic carbon measurement sensors.

question: Which of the following variables is not included, among those accepted, in the Biogeochemical mission of the Argo program?

answers.answer: Phosphate.
Dissolved oxygen.
Nitrate.
pH.
It is an Argo program management office present in each country and dependent on national programs.
It is an Argo program management office that provides support and infrastructure independent of national programs.
It is an entity that finances the Argo program.
It is an entity that evaluates national programs.

question: The Argo program uses the NetCDF format for data distribution. From this format it can be said:

answers.answer: It is a non-proprietary format, developed by IFREMER for Argo but only used in the marine science community.
It is a non-proprietary format, developed mainly by UNIDATA, which is a community of users of the American Corporation of Universities for Research in Atmospheric Sciences (UCAR).
It is part of the Java programming language, and therefore it is no longer proprietary, as SUN develops it under the GNU General Public License.
None of the above statements is true.

question: Which of the following statements in relation to the Argo program is not correct:

answers.answer: The goal of launching 2000 buoys is about to be reached.
It has among its objectives the systematic measurement of the ocean and the assimilation in present time of the data in models.
Coverage is one buoy every 3 degrees.
The data obtained by the Argo buoys are used in research.

question: How deep can Deep Argo type floats operate?

answers.answer: Up to 2000 meters deep.
Up to 8000 meters deep.
Up to 6000 meters deep.
Up to an average of the world's ocean depth.
